children.value: Had to share this one since it's so nice and simple. If you're looking for a drop-in, zero-dependency Google Maps React component, look no further.
To use it, simply grab a free Google Maps API key from
) and either add it to your
file or paste it in directly for
Then simply drop in the above
component wherever you'd like to display a Google map.

You might be wondering why we provide
component if all it does with them is pass them on as second argument to the
function. Wouldn't it be cleaner to
and then pass it into the
. That was indeed my first implementation. The problem with this approach is the
component has no way of knowing that it needs to rerender in case the
change (say because the user clicked a button to display another marker on the map). That will only work if
receives the new array of markers directly as props.

component will rerender whenever the parent component rerenders. There are two problems with this. First, it wastes computation since there's no need to rerender the map if its props didn't change. Second and more importantly, it ruins the user experience since the map will jump back to its initial
on every rerender. To prevent this, you can easily create a memoized map with the

import React, { useCallback } from 'react' // highlight-line import Map from 'components/map.js' const MemoMap = useCallback(, []) // highlight-line export default () => (

This is a memoized map

{MemoMap} // highlight-line
)
In fact, you may want to make memoization part of the
shallowly compares props and only rerenders a function component if the comparison returns false. It's the equivalent of

for class components. For components that receive objects, arrays and functions as props which are often referentially different on every render, the default behavior of shallow prop comparison can be overridden by passing a custom comparison function as second argument. It takes the next and previous props as input and returns true if the update should be skipped or false if the component should rerender.
to first identify and remove all (top-level) functions from
(in the above example, this only handles the
function but you may use additional functions in the future that would automatically be handled correctly by
). It then deep-compares the remaining props using
followed by comparing the string representations of all omitted functions. If both comparisons return true, it skips the rerender and the user gets to keep the map's current position and zoom level.
One little gotcha that took me some time to figure out is that you also need to modify the
to work correctly. The problem is that the Google Maps API modifies the
). But only on the first render. The options object of subsequent renders remains unchanged. So on the first call to
component will think it needs to rerender even though nothing has changed. To fix this, we simply pass the
object rather than the object itself.
Putting all of the above together, here's the full component that I use in production.
